elements.content: Insights into developing innovative routes for the stabilization of photogenerated charge-separated states by suppressing charge recombination in photocatalysts is a topic of immense importance. Herein, we report the synthesis of a metal–organic framework (MOF)-based composite where CdS nanoparticles (NPs) are confined inside the nanosized pores of Zr4+-based MOF-808, namely, CdS@MOF-808. Anchoring l-cysteine into the nanospace of MOF-808 via postsynthetic ligand exchange allows the capture of Cd2+ ions from their aqueous solution, which are further utilized for in situ growth of CdS NPs inside the nanosized MOF pores. The formation of CdS@MOF-808 opens up a possibility for visible-light photocatalysis as CdS NPs (1–2 nm) are a well-studied semiconductor system with a band gap of ∼2.6 eV. The confinement of the CdS NPs inside the MOF pores, close to the Zr4+ cluster, opens up a shorter electron transfer route from CdS to the catalytic Zr4+ cluster and shows a high rate of H2 evolution (10.41 mmol g–1 h–1) from water with a loading of 3.56 wt % CdS. In contrast, a similar composite in which CdS NPs are stabilized on the external surface of MOF-808 reveals poor activity (0.15 mmol g–1 h–1). CdS NPs stabilized on the MOF-808 surface show slower and inefficient electron transfer kinetics compared to CdS stabilized inside the nanospace of the MOF, as realized by the transient absorption measurements. Therefore, this work unveils the critical role of stabilizing the photosensitizer NPs in close proximity of the catalytic sites in MOF systems towards developing highly efficient H2 evolution photocatalysts.

elements.content: Light-mediated catalytic reactions play key roles in the conversion of solar photons to potential fuels via light–matter interaction. Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution by water reduction has emerged as a promising alternative strategy to meet the ever-increasing global demand for energy crisis and to combat environmental concerns regarding nonrenewable fossil fuels. In the past few years, a significant amount of research has been directed towards the development of artificial photocatalytic systems that can efficiently generate H2 from water.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Light-mediated catalytic reactions play key roles in the conversion of solar photons to potential fuels via light-matter interaction. Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution by water reduction has emerged as a promising alternative strategy to meet the ever-increasing global demand for energy crisis and to combat environmental concerns regarding nonrenewable fossil fuels. In the past few years, a significant amount of research has been directed towards the development of artificial photocatalytic systems that can efficiently generate H2 from water.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been recognized as a new generation of emerging porous materials in photocatalysis. The intrinsic coordination between metal or metal clusters and organic linkers in MOFs provides great flexibility toward the modulation of their semiconducting properties for enhanced light harvesting. The insoluble character of MOFs ensures heterogeneous catalysis for easy recycling, and their open channels favor the diffusion of substrates and products with minimized mass-transfer limit. Most importantly, the highly porous structure of MOFs makes them ideal host platforms for the encapsulation of other functional materials such as nanoparticles (NPs) which can act as either photosensitizers or catalytic centers. Interestingly, the synergy between these materials manifests in MOF composites exhibiting enhanced or even novel properties compared to the corresponding single-component systems. The effect of nanopore confinement of photosensitizing NPs upon the photocatalytic activity in MOF composites is of paramount importance for the construction of high-yield catalytic systems. However, very limited studies have been carried out in this direction. In general, spatial organization of the light-harvesting and the catalytic centers in close proximity is known to be instrumental towards driving efficient electron transfer kinetics, minimizing photobleaching and other unwanted competing reactions. Moreover, spatial confinement of NPs inside the MOF pores imparts morphological stability, which is often a huge challenge for composites where NPs are supported on the MOF surface. The quest for the development of noble/inexpensive metal-free photocatalysts has led to investigations into promising alternatives such as transition-metal oxides and sulfides. Among these, cadmium sulfide (CdS) is a prominent semiconductor that has been extensively studied for photocatalytic activity including H2 evolution from water owing to its good visible-light absorption ability and suitable conduction band (CB) position. However, achieving high yields of H2 production where CdS is utilized for light harvesting has several drawbacks concerning agglomeration of the NPs, photocorrosion, and rapid recombination of photoinduced exciton pairs. Herein, in situ-grown CdS NPs confined inside MOF nanopores provide a promising platform to defeat the aforementioned drawbacks. To the best of our knowledge, such a photocatalytic system is yet to be investigated. Herein, postsynthetically grafting one of the precursors, preferably the S2– source to the MOF secondary building unit (SBU), can allow the MOF to act as a heavy-metal ion trap for the efficient capture of Cd2+ ions for the ensuing generation of CdS NPs inside the MOF pores. Moreover, Cd2+ is well known as a wastewater contaminant and employing a MOF-based heavy-metal trap for the capture of Cd2+ from its aqueous solutions and its conversion to CdS offers a two-way environmental remediation scheme producing clean water and a green fuel, all by recycling the waste product of one process to the benefit of the other.

elements.content: In this study, we demonstrate the functioning of a heavy-metal ion trap formed by grafting l-cysteine (l-cys) onto Zr4+-based MOF-808 [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2] via postsynthetic ligand exchange (PSLE) to form MOF-808-cys. l-Cys is well-known as a source of S2– for the synthesis of a variety of metal-sulfide NPs, many of which are prominent photo- and electrocatalyst systems. The tolerance of MOFs linked by Zr4+-based clusters towards harsh chemical and mechanical conditions makes them ideal platforms for introducing functionalities employing PSLE, and MOF-808 is itself a robust system with a wide pore arrangement. The resulting functionalized MOF showed structural retention and affinity towards heavy-metal ions such as Cd2+ in aqueous media. In situ growth of CdS NPs inside the MOF pores was realized at elevated temperatures under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, it is well established that the Zr4+ cluster is capable of acting as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic water splitting or CO2 reduction. Therefore, the confinement of CdS NPs in the MOF nanopores in close proximity to the Zr4+ cluster not only opens up a facile and shorter electron transfer channel that suppresses electron–hole recombination but also stabilizes the catalytic system by preventing self-agglomeration and photobleaching (). The observed rate of H2 evolution from water for CdS4@MOF-808 (composite with 3.56 wt % of CdS) is 10.41 mmol h–1 g–1. The pore confinement effect of CdS was realized by comparing the catalytic activity with that of the CdS/MOF-808-cys (catalyst with similar CdS loading but on the exterior MOF surface) nanocomposite, which showed 60 times lesser activity with much slower and inefficient electron transfer kinetics compared to CdS4@MOF-808, as realized by the transient absorption (TA) measurements.

elements.content: Zr4+-based MOF-808 formulated as Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2 has a 6,3 connected 3D framework with spn topology and possesses two types of cages: tetrahedral and adamantane. The adamantane cage, having an internal pore diameter of 16.1 Å, is formed by the tetrahedral cages acting as the vertices. To balance the charge, the coordination of the SBU is completed with five exchangeable formate ligands that are well-directed toward the spacious adamantane cage. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized MOF-808 (a) exhibited two peaks at 8.6 and 9.9°, typical of MOF-808. Importantly, the observed pattern demonstrated unshifted peaks when compared with the simulated pattern obtained from its single-crystal structure analysis. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was also characterized employing FT-IR spectroscopy (Figure S1) and 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S2). The morphology of MOF-808 was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), wherein octahedral particles of size around 200–250 nm were observed (d). The lattice fringe spacing calculated was 1.64 nm, which is typical for MOF-808, and the result is consistent with the pore size obtained from the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) methods based on N2 adsorption data at 77 K (d inset). N2 adsorption study (at 77 K) was performed to validate the permanent porosity of MOF-808 (b). The BET surface area was 2418 m2 g–1, which is in good agreement with the previous reports of Zr4+-based MOF-808. The high internal surface area, large cavity size, excellent stability in aqueous solutions, and, most importantly, the presence of appropriately oriented and exchangeable formate ions on the Zr6 cluster makes Zr4+-based MOF-808 an ideal platform for postsynthetic modification with l-cys. The robustness of the structure of MOF-808 after functionalizing with l-cys was confirmed by PXRD studies (a), where similar peak positions were observed when compared with the pristine MOF-808. 1H NMR studies of alkaline digested MOF-808 exhibited two characteristic peaks at chemical shift values of 8.28 and 8.20 ppm corresponding to the protons of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) and formate ligands. The peak integration ratio of these two peaks confirmed the presence of six BTC and five formate units in the framework. However, for MOF-808-cys, this resulting ratio indicated the presence of six BTC units and one formate unit, thereby confirming the successful exchange of four formate ligands by l-cys (Figure S4). The FT-IR spectra for MOF-808-cys showed two new peaks at 2310 and 1190 cm–1 corresponding to the S–H and C–N symmetric stretching, respectively, further confirming the presence of the l-cys molecule in the MOF-808 framework (Figure S3). TEM images of MOF-808-cys (e,f) reveal an octahedral morphology, thereby confirming no significant change in morphology upon covalent grafting of l-cys. The presence of S and N in the elemental mapping of MOF-808-cys (g and S5) also illustrates the incorporation of l-cys into the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Zr4+-based MOF-808 formulated as Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2 has a 6,3 connected 3D framework with spn topology and possesses two types of cages: tetrahedral and adamantane. The adamantane cage, having an internal pore diameter of 16.1 Å, is formed by the tetrahedral cages acting as the vertices. To balance the charge, the coordination of the SBU is completed with five exchangeable formate ligands that are well-directed toward the spacious adamantane cage. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized MOF-808 (a) exhibited two peaks at 8.6 and 9.9°, typical of MOF-808. Importantly, the observed pattern demonstrated unshifted peaks when compared with the simulated pattern obtained from its single-crystal structure analysis. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was also characterized employing FT-IR spectroscopy (Figure S1) and 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S2). The morphology of MOF-808 was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), wherein octahedral particles of size around 200-250 nm were observed (d). The lattice fringe spacing calculated was 1.64 nm, which is typical for MOF-808, and the result is consistent with the pore size obtained from the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) methods based on N2 adsorption data at 77 K (d inset). N2 adsorption study (at 77 K) was performed to validate the permanent porosity of MOF-808 (b). The BET surface area was 2418 m2 g-1, which is in good agreement with the previous reports of Zr4+-based MOF-808. The high internal surface area, large cavity size, excellent stability in aqueous solutions, and, most importantly, the presence of appropriately oriented and exchangeable formate ions on the Zr6 cluster makes Zr4+-based MOF-808 an ideal platform for postsynthetic modification with l-cys. The robustness of the structure of MOF-808 after functionalizing with l-cys was confirmed by PXRD studies (a), where similar peak positions were observed when compared with the pristine MOF-808. 1H NMR studies of alkaline digested MOF-808 exhibited two characteristic peaks at chemical shift values of 8.28 and 8.20 ppm corresponding to the protons of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) and formate ligands. The peak integration ratio of these two peaks confirmed the presence of six BTC and five formate units in the framework. However, for MOF-808-cys, this resulting ratio indicated the presence of six BTC units and one formate unit, thereby confirming the successful exchange of four formate ligands by l-cys (Figure S4). The FT-IR spectra for MOF-808-cys showed two new peaks at 2310 and 1190 cm-1 corresponding to the S-H and C-N symmetric stretching, respectively, further confirming the presence of the l-cys molecule in the MOF-808 framework (Figure S3). TEM images of MOF-808-cys (e,f) reveal an octahedral morphology, thereby confirming no significant change in morphology upon covalent grafting of l-cys. The presence of S and N in the elemental mapping of MOF-808-cys (g and S5) also illustrates the incorporation of l-cys into the framework.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements (Figure S6) demonstrated weight loss in two steps and a total of 40 and 56% weight loss up to 800 °C for MOF-808 and MOF-808-cys, respectively. It was also observed that MOF-808-cys could maintain good thermal stability up to 250 °C, which is in good consistency with that of pristine MOF-808. A significant decrease in the N2 uptake (b) and the corresponding BET surface area from 2418 to 562 m2 g–1 further validates the incorporation of l-cys in the framework. The pore size distribution (c) showed a reduction of pore size from 1.60 to 0.86 nm after postsynthetic modification with l-cys. However, the cavity size for MOF-808-cys is still spacious enough for efficient mass transfer to take place.

elements.content: l-Cys is widely used as a precursor in the synthesis of metal sulfides accredited to the presence of the thiol group. Initially, the metal ions interact with l-cys to form precursor complexes, which undergo decomposition to produce metal sulfide composites as the reaction temperature increases. When soaked in a 20 ppm aqueous solution of Cd2+, MOF-808-cys showed removal of Cd2+ ions owing to the presence of free metal-binding sites. This observation was evident from inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurements. Similar observations were found for other heavy-metal ions such as Pb2+ and Hg2+, and the samples were named MOF-808-cys-M (M2+ = Cd2+, Pb2+, and Hg2+). In concentrations as low as 5 ppm, MOF-808-cys is capable of acting as a heavy-metal ion trap for removing Cd2+, Pb2+, and Hg2+ from their respective aqueous solutions with a removal efficiency >99% (Table S1). The resulting solution contained metal ion concentrations lower than the admissible limits in drinking water standards of the WHO. PXRD patterns of the metal captured samples (Figure S9) exhibited unaltered peak positions compared to the l-cys-functionalized MOF-808, suggesting that the MOF structure is retained after the capture of metal ions. The successful binding of the heavy metal ions was confirmed from FT-IR spectra (Figure S10) as the intensity of the S–H symmetric stretching peak at 2310 cm–1 for MOF-808-cys shows a significant decrease upon capturing the heavy-metal ions from the aqueous solution. A small shift to higher wavenumbers observed for the peak can be accredited to the rigidification of the S–H bond upon metal ion coordination. TEM images of the MOF-808-cys-M samples illustrated the intactness of the octahedral morphology (Figure S11). The capture of the metal ions was further validated from the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images and the corresponding elemental mappings (Figures S12–S14). For real-time analysis, MOF-808-cys was also tested against water samples from a nearby waterbody, and the corresponding elemental mapping (Figure S15) showed ample amounts of Pb2+ and Hg2+ uptake. The MOF-808-cys-Cd samples obtained from the 20 ppm Cd2+ solution were subjected to heating at 60 °C to unravel the decomposition of l-cys and consequential formation of cadmium sulfide composites. From ICP-OES analysis, the wt % of CdS formed within the MOF pores was calculated to be 1.18%. Correspondingly, the sample was named CdS1@MOF-808. The CdS1@MOF-808 sample showed peaks corresponding to the metal sulfide NPs in its PXRD pattern (Figure S16). The N2 uptake and the BET surface area (b) showed an increase for CdS1@MOF-808 as compared to those for both MOF-808-cys and MOF-808-cys-Cd, which was in good accordance with the breaking of the l-cys moiety to form metal sulfide NPs at elevated temperatures. We hypothesized that MOF-808-cys acts as a template for the in situ growth of metal sulfide NPs within its nanosized cavities. This proposed phenomenon was validated from the TEM images of the metal captured samples which clearly showed NPs having diameters in the range of 1–2 nm under high magnification (a–c). The lattice fringe spacings (b inset) of CdS1@MOF-808 were calculated to be 0.33 and 0.19 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (220) planes of the cubic CdS system, respectively, thereby confirming our conjecture of in situ growth of metal sulfide NPs. This was further clarified from the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (c), which confirmed the presence of the two aforementioned planes for the crystalline CdS NPs.

elements.content: CdS1@MOF-808 exhibited considerable absorption of visible light, as evident from a significant peak at 410 nm in its absorption spectrum (a). This peak at 410 nm was attributed to the charge transfer from the valence band (VB) primarily having the 3p character of the S atom to the empty CB, which majorly has the 5s character of the Cd2+ center. Interestingly, CdS is one of the most prominent visible-light-responsive semiconductor photocatalysts for solar-fuel generation due to its efficient visible-light absorption and excellent carrier transport capacity. Herein, the band gap of CdS1@MOF-808 was calculated to be 2.60 eV from the Tauc plot (Figure S19), thereby suggesting a narrow band gap that is suitable for visible-light-driven photocatalysis as opposed to the wide band gap of around 4.02 eV observed for MOF-808-cys (Figure S18). The flat band potential and, consequently, the relative alignment of the VB and CB were evaluated from the Mott–Schottky plots (b,c). The observed flat band potential of the sample is −0.51 V. The suitable band alignment and narrow band gap of CdS1@MOF-808 enthused us to study its photocatalytic activity for the visible-light-driven hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) by water reduction. Herein, the photocatalytic activity of an aqueous dispersion of CdS1@MOF-808 was evaluated under visible-light (λ > 400 nm) irradiation by employing triethylamine (TEA) as the sacrificial agent, and the time course for H2 evolution was monitored by gas chromatography (d). After a period of 12 h, 1.01 mmol g–1 H2 evolved. To enhance the photocatalytic activity of the nanocomposites even further, the wt % of CdS formed was enhanced to 1.84 and 3.56% by increasing the concentration of the Cd2+ aqueous solution to 50 and 150 ppm, and the samples were named CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808, respectively. The robustness of the structure of these two samples was verified by PXRD analysis (Figure S16). In line with the morphological analysis of CdS1@MOF-808, CdS NPs of 1–2 nm diameter were found confined inside the MOF pores and not on the exterior surface of the MOF for both CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808 (d, S20, and S21). However, further drastically increasing the concentration of the aqueous solution of Cd2+ to 0.1 M led to the formation of larger CdS NPs (size ∼ 20 nm) on the MOF surface (Figure S22), and therefore, the CdS loading inside the pore was not amplified beyond what was obtained for CdS4@MOF-808. Both CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808 showed similar absorption spectra and flat band potential (Figures S23 and S24) as that observed for CdS1@MOF-808, and hence, the photocatalytic activities of these two samples were tested subsequently. The amount of H2 evolved after 12 h of reaction shot up from 2.42 to 125.79 mmol g–1 for CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808, respectively (d,f). Recyclability of CdS1@MOF-808, CdS2@MOF-808, and CdS4@MOF-808 as photocatalysts was tested under similar reaction conditions by degassing the samples after every 4 h cycle. The photocatalytic performances of all samples were consistent even after 4 cycles (e and S25) and hence were rendered extremely stable. Notably, CdS4@MOF-808 demonstrated an extremely high photocatalytic activity with a rate of 10.41 mmol g–1 h–1. Raman spectroscopy is an extremely effective tool to study small changes corresponding to the local environment of the molecule, chemical bond, and so forth. The Raman peak observed at 303 cm–1 for the pristine CdS NPs corresponds to the first-order longitudinal optical phonon (A1-LO) scattering from the CdS NPs (Figure S26). Interestingly, in case of CdS4@MOF-808, this peak shifted to a higher energy value at 401 cm–1. This could possibly be attributed to the freezing of several degrees of rotational and vibrational freedom owing to the confinement inside the MOF nanopores. After 12 h of photocatalytic reaction, the Raman spectrum of CdS4@MOF-808 showed no changes for the peak corresponding to CdS and for the MOF peaks, thereby suggesting no change in its chemical composition and interaction of the elements. The surface charge of CdS4@MOF-808 was analyzed by ζ-potential measurements before and after photocatalysis (Figure S27). CdS4@MOF-808 shows an intense peak at a ζ-potential value 0 mV, indicating the fact that the net surface charge on the MOF is neutral. A similar phenomenon is observed for the sample after 12 h of photocatalytic reaction, thereby signifying no change in the surface charge of the MOF. The photocatalytic activity of CdS4@MOF-808 was analyzed in basic (TEA), acidic (l-ascorbic acid), and neutral (methanol) media (Figure S28). Since the H2 evolution activity observed in basic media was the highest, further HER studies were carried out in basic media using TEA as the sacrificial agent. In order to confirm the photocatalytic HER by CdS4@MOF-808, several control studies were carried out under varying reaction conditions (Figure S29). No H2 evolution was observed from a visible-light irradiated mixture of H2O and TEA, thereby ruling out the possibility of any H2 generation from the solvent or sacrificial agent. Negligible H2 was evolved using bare MOF-808-cys or even MOF-808-cys-Cd, where Cd2+ ions are simply coordinated to the l-cys moiety under visible-light irradiation using TEA as the sacrificial agent. This, in turn, highlights the importance of formation of CdS NPs inside the MOF for efficient photosensitizing, which is crucial for photocatalysts. Finally, the lack of H2 generation by CdS4@MOF-808 in the dark with otherwise similar reaction conditions confirms the photocatalytic nature of the HER. The apparent quantum efficiency after irradiation at 400 nm was calculated to be 3.28% for CdS4@MOF-808 (see Supporting Information for detailed calculation). HER tests using CdS4@MOF-808 were also performed for a time course of 36 h to demonstrate consistent performance and long-term stability of the photocatalyst (Figure S30). Intactness of the pristine MOF structure was confirmed by PXRD analysis, and the morphological stability of CdS4@MOF-808 was confirmed by TEM analysis, wherein no agglomeration or leaching of CdS NPs were observed (Figures S31 and S32). The H2 evolution activity of CdS4@MOF-808 without an external photosensitizer or cocatalyst was more or less equal to or greater than several recently reported NP–MOF composite photocatalysts (Table S2).

elements.content: The development of new and innovative routes for stabilization of the charge-separated states by suppressing charge recombination in photocatalysts has been a topic of immense interest for years. In this context, it was observed that photoinduced electron transfer (PET) from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the CdS moiety to the empty LUMO of the Zr4+ cluster of MOF-808-cys could open up a catalytic path for manifesting in excellent photocatalytic activity of the system. Confinement of CdS NPs in close proximity to the catalytic center, that is, the Zr4+ cluster, helps dock and separate electron–hole pairs by opening up a shorter electron transfer route, resulting in stabilization of the excited-state electron and rendering it more available for catalytic reactions. To study this phenomenon in detail, a comparative study was carried out between two photocatalytic systems, CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys, having different locations of CdS NPs in the MOF-808 (Figure S33). Unlike CdS4@MOF-808, in case of CdS/MOF-808-cys, the presynthesized CdS NPs of 1–2 nm were stabilized on the surface of MOF-808-cys. From ICP-OES analysis, the amount of CdS present in CdS/MOF-808-cys was found to be 3.82 wt %, which is almost equal to that observed for CdS4@MOF-808. TEM images of CdS/MOF-808-cys showed the presence of CdS NPs on the external surface of the MOF (e). The photocatalytic activity observed for CdS/MOF-808-cys (0.15 mmol g–1 h–1) (f) was almost 60 times lower compared to that observed for CdS4@MOF-808. Recyclability tests demonstrated that the photocatalytic activity of CdS/MOF-808-cys gradually decreases with each cycle (Figure S25). Although the crystalline MOF structure remains intact post-photocatalytic reaction (Figure S34), considerably large agglomerations of CdS NPs on the MOF surface were observed for CdS/MOF-808-cys (Figures S38–S40). However, CdS NPs in CdS4@MOF-808 continued to maintain a uniform dispersion inside the MOF pores, as validated from TEM and FESEM images (Figures S35–S37). This further accentuates the fact that in an unconfined state, CdS NPs tend to agglomerate and undergo photobleaching, thereby reducing the overall photocatalytic activity of the system. To gain an insight into the factors responsible for such differential activity of the two samples, photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) studies were carried out. The photocurrent response (a) of the as-prepared samples was examined in a three-electrode photoelectrochemical cell with multiple 30 s on–off cycles under visible-light irradiation. CdS4@MOF-808 exhibited a much higher current density as compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys, suggesting a large separation rate of the photoinduced electron–hole pairs, and consequentially, higher efficiency of charge transfer from CdS to the MOF in the former was conjectured. The EIS–Nyquist plot of CdS4@MOF-808 (b) demonstrated a smaller circular radius than that of CdS/MOF-808-cys, therefore indicating a lower charge-transfer resistance of the former sample. Moreover, the photocurrent response and EIS analysis of MOF-808-cys individually revealed negligible charge transfer, thereby emphasizing the importance of CdS in this system for any PET process to occur, and most importantly, the enhanced charge-transfer efficiency of CdS4@MOF-808 compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys solely arises from the confinement of the CdS NPs inside the MOF pores. Furthermore, photophysical studies were employed to investigate the efficiency of charge carrier trapping and transfer in the photocatalysts. The photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of both CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys (c) showed a peak at 504 nm corresponding to the radiative recombination of the photogenerated electrons and holes. However, significant quenching of PL intensity was observed for CdS4@MOF-808 as compared to that of CdS/MOF-808-cys, indicating that the former showed enhanced separation efficiency of the photogenerated electron–hole pairs. The lifetime of the charge carriers was studied via luminescence decay measurements (d and Table S3), wherein CdS4@MOF-808 demonstrated a shortened lifetime value of 2.02 ns as compared to CdS/MOF-808-cys, which has a lifetime of 4.03 ns. To further understand the charge-transfer kinetics of the photogenerated electrons and origin of higher current density in CdS4@MOF-808 than CdS/MOF-808-cys observed in EIS studies, femtosecond TA experiments were performed. The TA spectra of CdS/MOF-808-cys in the visible region for different times are shown in Figure S41a. At initial time, the spectra of the sample showed a negative TA band (B1) with a peak ∼480 nm and a broad negative band (B2) spanning over 520–700 nm. The TA spectra of the sample also revealed a positive absorption band (A1) below 440 nm. Following the literature report, B1, B2, and A1 bands are assigned to the exciton bleach due to the state filling of the 1S­(e) level at the CB of CdS, stimulated emission, and the excitonic absorption due to the presence of multiple excitons, respectively. Significant quenching of all three bands in the presence of methyl viologen clearly indicates that an electron rather than a hole mainly contributes to these spectral bands (Figure S41b). Since the excitonic bleach band B1 represents the population of the electron in the 1S­(e) state, its dynamics corresponds to the depopulation of the electron at the CB. Hence, to understand the fate of electrons, the dynamics of the B1 band has been analyzed. The fitting of B1 band decay kinetics results in the decay time constants of 0.83 ps (33%), 21 ps (53%), and 3.12 ns (14%) for CdS/MOF-808-cys. The two fast decay time constants are due to the trapping of the electron in the shallow and deep trap state, respectively. The longest lifetime (3.12 ns) is due to the recombination of the CB edge electron with the trapped hole. A similar TA spectral feature has been observed for CdS4@MOF-808 (e) except that the B1 band is centered at ∼460 nm than 480 nm in CdS/MOF-808-cys. Such difference in the spectral position is due to the agglomeration of CdS NPs in CdS/MOF-808-cys. The kinetics of the B1 band for CdS4@MOF-808 has been compared with CdS/MOF-808-cys, and the result is shown in f. Similar analysis of the B1 band for CdS4@MOF-808 results in the decay time constants of 0.22 ps (44%), 13.2 ps (31%), and 384 ps (25%). Hence, the lifetime of excitonic electrons in the CB of CdS NPs reduces significantly due to its incorporation inside the MOF cavity as compared to the CdS NPs residing on the external surface of the MOF. This result is also in accordance with the significant quenching of PL and shorter PL lifetime in CdS4@MOF-808 than CdS/MOF-808-cys.

elements.content: The above-mentioned differentiated properties of CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys can be attributed to the proposed phenomenon of electron transfer from the encapsulated CdS to the Zr4+ cluster of the MOF. In the case of CdS4@MOF-808, the confinement effect of CdS inside the MOF pores facilitates efficient electron transfer from CdS to the MOF owing to the proximity of the two components. To further support the following hypothesis, theoretical studies were carried out. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation prevailed the authenticity of PET from CdS NPs to the Zr4+ cluster of the MOF. Frontier molecular orbital analysis showed that the LUMO of Zr4+ cluster is low-lying than the LUMO of CdS NPs. This demonstrated the feasibility of transfer of the photoexcited electron from the LUMO of CdS NPs to the LUMO of the Zr4+ cluster (a), which in turn makes the Zr4+ center as the active catalytic site for water splitting. This phenomenon was further supported by electron spin resonance (ESR) (b), wherein a signal corresponding to the Zr3+ intermediate (g = 2.001) was observed by the electron transfer from CdS to the Zr4+ cluster for CdS4@MOF-808 upon irradiation (λ > 400 nm). Such electron-accepting and catalytic activity by the Zr4+ cluster has been demonstrated earlier. From Mott–Schottky analysis, the CB of MOF-808-cys was evaluated to be positioned at −0.48 V, whereas the reduction reaction of water to hydrogen occurs at −0.41 V (Figure S42). Therefore, the utilization of excited electrons from the CB of MOF-808-cys for water reduction reaction is energetically feasible, making the Zr4+ cluster the catalytic center for the HER. This, therefore, corroborates the importance of confinement of CdS inside the MOF pores, which facilitates the electron transfer process. On the contrary, in case of CdS/MOF-808-cys, the electron transfer phenomenon is not efficient enough to provoke an ESR signal, which also accounts for its poor photocatalytic activity.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism and Theoretical Studies

The above-mentioned differentiated properties of CdS4@MOF-808 and CdS/MOF-808-cys can be attributed to the proposed phenomenon of electron transfer from the encapsulated CdS to the Zr4+ cluster of the MOF. In the case of CdS4@MOF-808, the confinement effect of CdS inside the MOF pores facilitates efficient electron transfer from CdS to the MOF owing to the proximity of the two components. To further support the following hypothesis, theoretical studies were carried out. The density functional theory (DFT) calculation prevailed the authenticity of PET from CdS NPs to the Zr4+ cluster of the MOF. Frontier molecular orbital analysis showed that the LUMO of Zr4+ cluster is low-lying than the LUMO of CdS NPs. This demonstrated the feasibility of transfer of the photoexcited electron from the LUMO of CdS NPs to the LUMO of the Zr4+ cluster (a), which in turn makes the Zr4+ center as the active catalytic site for water splitting. This phenomenon was further supported by electron spin resonance (ESR) (b), wherein a signal corresponding to the Zr3+ intermediate (g = 2.001) was observed by the electron transfer from CdS to the Zr4+ cluster for CdS4@MOF-808 upon irradiation (λ > 400 nm). Such electron-accepting and catalytic activity by the Zr4+ cluster has been demonstrated earlier. From Mott-Schottky analysis, the CB of MOF-808-cys was evaluated to be positioned at -0.48 V, whereas the reduction reaction of water to hydrogen occurs at -0.41 V (Figure S42). Therefore, the utilization of excited electrons from the CB of MOF-808-cys for water reduction reaction is energetically feasible, making the Zr4+ cluster the catalytic center for the HER. This, therefore, corroborates the importance of confinement of CdS inside the MOF pores, which facilitates the electron transfer process. On the contrary, in case of CdS/MOF-808-cys, the electron transfer phenomenon is not efficient enough to provoke an ESR signal, which also accounts for its poor photocatalytic activity.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel strategy was developed for manifold enhancement of photocatalytic activity by the spatial confinement of photosensitizing CdS NPs inside the nanospace of Zr4+-based MOF-808 in close proximity to the catalytic Zr4+ cluster. Efficient visible-light-driven H2 production was achieved for CdS4@MOF-808 (10.41 mmol h–1 g–1), which was 60 times higher compared to a similar MOF composite, where CdS NPs were simply supported on the MOF surface. Detailed studies showed that the key factors responsible for such difference in photocatalytic activity of the two similar MOF composites stem from suppressed electron–hole recombination via fast and efficient electron transfer kinetics from CdS to the Zr4+ cluster inside the nanospace. The confinement effect induces a shorter electron transfer route from the photosensitizer to catalytic center, resulting in better photogenerated charge separation. This work, therefore, opens up a new direction towards tuning the structure of photocatalytic systems so as to realize shorter electron transfer routes in order to achieve enhanced photocatalytic yields for reactions such as hydrogen evolution, CO2 reduction, and so on.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a novel strategy was developed for manifold enhancement of photocatalytic activity by the spatial confinement of photosensitizing CdS NPs inside the nanospace of Zr4+-based MOF-808 in close proximity to the catalytic Zr4+ cluster. Efficient visible-light-driven H2 production was achieved for CdS4@MOF-808 (10.41 mmol h-1 g-1), which was 60 times higher compared to a similar MOF composite, where CdS NPs were simply supported on the MOF surface. Detailed studies showed that the key factors responsible for such difference in photocatalytic activity of the two similar MOF composites stem from suppressed electron-hole recombination via fast and efficient electron transfer kinetics from CdS to the Zr4+ cluster inside the nanospace. The confinement effect induces a shorter electron transfer route from the photosensitizer to catalytic center, resulting in better photogenerated charge separation. This work, therefore, opens up a new direction towards tuning the structure of photocatalytic systems so as to realize shorter electron transfer routes in order to achieve enhanced photocatalytic yields for reactions such as hydrogen evolution, CO2 reduction, and so on.

Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2⋅8H2O, purity ≥ 99.5%), benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC), l-cysteine, lead nitrate [Pb(NO3)2], mercury nitrate monohydrate [Hg(NO3)2⋅H2O], and cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate [Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O] were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), formic acid (purity > 98%), and anhydrous acetone were purchased from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd. All photophysical studies were carried out using HPLC-grade solvents.

elements.content: Elemental analyses were performed using a Thermo Scientific Flash 2000 CHN analyzer. Infrared spectroscopic studies were performed using a Bruker IFS 66v/S spectrometer by making samples with KBr pellets. Thermal stability of the materials was analyzed by TGA using Mettler-Toledo TGA 850 under an inert atmosphere (N2 flow rate = 50 mol min–1) in the temperature range of 25–850 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. PXRD patterns were recorded using a Bruker D8 Discover instrument (40 kV, 30 mA) using Cu Kα radiation. 1H NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker AV-400 with chemical shifts recorded as parts per million and all spectra calibrated against tetramethylsilane. The adsorption isotherm of N2 at 77 K was recorded for the dehydrated sample using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ analyzer. To prepare dehydrated samples, 100 mg of the sample was degassed at 120 °C at 1 bar vacuum for 10 h before commencing measurements. The dead volume of the sample cell was measured using He of 99.999% purity. The amount of adsorbed gas was calculated from the pressure difference (P cal – P e), where P cal is the calculated pressure with no gas adsorption and P e is the observed equilibrium pressure. All operations were automatic and computer-controlled. Morphological studies were performed employing a Leica-S440I field emission scanning electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 100 kV under high vacuum. The samples were dispersed in ethanol and drop-cast on a silicon wafer. TEM analysis was performed using JEOL JFM-F200 with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For this analysis, the samples were dispersed in ethanol by ultrasonic treatment, drop-cast on a holey carbon-coated copper grid, and dried overnight under vacuum. ICP-OES measurements were recorded using a PerkinElmer Optima 7000dv ICP-OES instrument. Solid-state UV–vis spectra were recorded in reflectance mode using a PerkinElmer model Lambda 900 spectrophotometer. PL studies were carried out using a Fluorolog 3.21 spectrofluorometer (HORIBA Jobin-Yvon) instrument. The fluorescence decay profiles of the samples were recorded using a Horiba DeltaFlex time-correlated single-photon counting instrument. A 405 nm laser diode with a pulse repetition rate of 1 MHz was utilized as the light source. A scatterer (Ludox AS40 colloidal silica, Sigma-Aldrich) was employed for the collection of the instrument response function. ESR studies of the solid sample were carried out using a JES-X320 instrument (using X-band microwave ES-11030 MWU; JEOL Resonance). ζ-potential analysis was carried out using Nano ZS (Malvern UK) using a 532 nm laser. Raman spectroscopy analysis was performed using a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope using a 785 nm laser.

elements.content: Photocatalytic H2 evolution experiments were carried out in a 75 mL stoppered flask. 5 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 35 mL of H2O, and subsequently, 3 mL of TEA was added to the dispersion. The suspension was then ultrasonicated to make a homogeneous dispersion, which was then purged with Ar to remove all other dissolved gases. The reaction mixture was then irradiated using a 300 W xenon lamp (Newport) fitted with a visible band-pass filter (400–800 nm) to block the UV light. The evolved gas was analyzed by gas chromatography [Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph which uses a thermal conductivity detector referencing against a standard gas mixture (H2/N2) with a known concentration of H2]. We measured the intensity of the light source using a power meter (Newport-843-R). The measured intensity during the catalytic reaction (λ = 400–800) was 98.2 mW/cm2. All solid samples were activated at 120 °C under 1 × 10–1 Pa vacuum in a Quantachrome sample cell for 24 h prior to commencing photocatalytic reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Reaction

Photocatalytic H2 evolution experiments were carried out in a 75 mL stoppered flask. 5 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 35 mL of H2O, and subsequently, 3 mL of TEA was added to the dispersion. The suspension was then ultrasonicated to make a homogeneous dispersion, which was then purged with Ar to remove all other dissolved gases. The reaction mixture was then irradiated using a 300 W xenon lamp (Newport) fitted with a visible band-pass filter (400-800 nm) to block the UV light. The evolved gas was analyzed by gas chromatography [Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph which uses a thermal conductivity detector referencing against a standard gas mixture (H2/N2) with a known concentration of H2]. We measured the intensity of the light source using a power meter (Newport-843-R). The measured intensity during the catalytic reaction (λ = 400-800) was 98.2 mW/cm2. All solid samples were activated at 120 °C under 1 × 10-1 Pa vacuum in a Quantachrome sample cell for 24 h prior to commencing photocatalytic reactions.

elements.content: The Mott–Schottky and impedance analyses were carried out using a CHI760E electrochemical workstation (CHI Instruments, USA) with a conventional three-electrode system in a 0.2 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Characterization

The Mott-Schottky and impedance analyses were carried out using a CHI760E electrochemical workstation (CHI Instruments, USA) with a conventional three-electrode system in a 0.2 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution.

elements.content: 2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) in a 1:1 ratio and 14 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. Glassy carbon electrodes (4 mm diameter) were used as working electrodes. Before the experiments, the glassy carbon electrode was polished on a polishing cloth to obtain a mirror-like surface. 8 μL of the catalyst ink was drop-cast on the glassy electrode surface and left to dry for 6 h at room temperature. The Mott–Schottky experiments were performed by employing frequencies of 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz with a 10 mV amplitude with various applied potentials using a platinum wire counter electrode and a standard Ag/AgCl reference electrode. EIS measurements were carried out by applying an AC voltage of 10 mV with the frequency ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz in the three-electrode system.
elements.clean_text:

2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) in a 1:1 ratio and 14 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. Glassy carbon electrodes (4 mm diameter) were used as working electrodes. Before the experiments, the glassy carbon electrode was polished on a polishing cloth to obtain a mirror-like surface. 8 μL of the catalyst ink was drop-cast on the glassy electrode surface and left to dry for 6 h at room temperature. The Mott-Schottky experiments were performed by employing frequencies of 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz with a 10 mV amplitude with various applied potentials using a platinum wire counter electrode and a standard Ag/AgCl reference electrode. EIS measurements were carried out by applying an AC voltage of 10 mV with the frequency ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz in the three-electrode system.

elements.content: 2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and IPA in a 1:1 ratio and 15 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was taken in an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. 500 μL of this slurry was coated on a 1 cm × 1 cm indium-doped tin oxide glass plate and dried at room temperature. The Ag/AgCl electrode was deployed as the reference electrode, and a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode. The transient photocurrent responses were studied under visible-light irradiation conditions (300 W xenon arc lamp).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Working Electrode for Transient Photocurrent Measurements

2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and IPA in a 1:1 ratio and 15 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was taken in an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. 500 μL of this slurry was coated on a 1 cm × 1 cm indium-doped tin oxide glass plate and dried at room temperature. The Ag/AgCl electrode was deployed as the reference electrode, and a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode. The transient photocurrent responses were studied under visible-light irradiation conditions (300 W xenon arc lamp).

elements.content: Details of the femtosecond TA spectrometer used in the present study have been described elsewhere. In brief, a second harmonic output (400 nm) of a Ti–sapphire laser pulse (800 nm, 1 kHz) from an amplified laser (Amplitude Technologies, France) was used for the excitation of the sample. Broad white light (420–650 nm) generated by focusing a 800 nm laser pulse onto a rotating CaF2 crystal was used as the probe and reference beams. The probe and reference beams were detected using a dual diode array-based spectrograph from CDP Corporation, Russia. All measurements were performed under magic-angle polarization conditions to eliminate any contribution due to the rotational depolarization in the measured data. The temporal resolution (FWHM) of the present transient setup was 120 fs. Samples were dispersed in 1-propanol by mixing them for 12 h. A thin (1.5 mm) rotating optical cell was used for minimizing the photodecomposition of samples. The pump power at the sample was 0.25 mW. All TA spectra were averaged for 2 s at each time point.

Broad white light (420-650 nm) generated by focusing a 800 nm laser pulse onto a rotating CaF2 crystal was used as the probe and reference beams. The probe and reference beams were detected using a dual diode array-based spectrograph from CDP Corporation, Russia. All measurements were performed under magic-angle polarization conditions to eliminate any contribution due to the rotational depolarization in the measured data. The temporal resolution (FWHM) of the present transient setup was 120 fs. Samples were dispersed in 1-propanol by mixing them for 12 h. elements.content: Microcrystalline powder samples of MOF-808 were prepared following previously reported procedures. Benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.21 g, 2 mmol) and ZrOCl2·8H2O salt (0.97 g, 6 mmol) were dissolved in DMF/formic acid (24.5 mL/24.5 mL) and placed in a screw-capped glass vial, which was then heated at 130 °C for 2 days. Subsequently, a white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed thrice with 25 mL of fresh DMF. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was then immersed in 5 mL of anhydrous DMF for 3 days, wherein DMF was replaced three times per day during this period. The DMF-exchanged compound was filtered and immersed in 15 mL of water, followed by anhydrous acetone, 3 days each. The solvents were replaced three times per day in a similar manner. The acetone-exchanged sample was then dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature followed by activation at 120 °C for 24 h to yield the desired compound (yield: 0.7 g, 79% based on Zr). 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.28 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:5.0. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C23H18O32 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2]: Zr, 40.42; C, 20.41; H, 1.34%. Found: Zr, 40.38; C, 20.10; H, 1.32%.

Synthesis

Microcrystalline Powder Samples of MOF-808

Microcrystalline powder samples of MOF-808 were prepared following previously reported procedures. Benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.21 g, 2 mmol) and ZrOCl2⋅8H2O salt (0.97 g, 6 mmol) were dissolved in DMF/formic acid (24.5 mL/24.5 mL) and placed in a screw-capped glass vial, which was then heated at 130 °C for 2 days. Subsequently, a white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed thrice with 25 mL of fresh DMF. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was then immersed in 5 mL of anhydrous DMF for 3 days, wherein DMF was replaced three times per day during this period. The DMF-exchanged compound was filtered and immersed in 15 mL of water, followed by anhydrous acetone, 3 days each. The solvents were replaced three times per day in a similar manner. The acetone-exchanged sample was then dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature followed by activation at 120 °C for 24 h to yield the desired compound (yield: 0.7 g, 79% based on Zr). 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.28 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:5.0. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C23H18O32 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2]: Zr, 40.42; C, 20.41; H, 1.34%. Found: Zr, 40.38; C, 20.10; H, 1.32%.

elements.content: Activated MOF-808 (0.100 g) was immersed in an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (0.1 M, 6 mL). The contents were kept in a screw-capped glass vial for 14 days. During this period, the l-cysteine solution was renewed every 4 days. The white precipitate was then filtered and washed with water several times to remove any trace of unreacted l-cysteine. Finally, the white solid powder obtained was dried under vacuum conditions to yield MOF-808-cys. 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.26 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:0.86. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C31H38O32N4 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)­(C3H7NO2S)­(H2O)2]: Zr, 35.57; C, 24.23; H, 2.47; N, 3.67%. Found: Zr, 34.23; C, 25.08; H, 2.68; N, 3.37%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF-808-cys

Activated MOF-808 (0.100 g) was immersed in an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (0.1 M, 6 mL). The contents were kept in a screw-capped glass vial for 14 days. During this period, the l-cysteine solution was renewed every 4 days. The white precipitate was then filtered and washed with water several times to remove any trace of unreacted l-cysteine. Finally, the white solid powder obtained was dried under vacuum conditions to yield MOF-808-cys. 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.26 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:0.86. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C31H38O32N4 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)(C3H7NO2S)(H2O)2]: Zr, 35.57; C, 24.23; H, 2.47; N, 3.67%. Found: Zr, 34.23; C, 25.08; H, 2.68; N, 3.37%.

elements.content: 35 mg of MOF-808-cys was immersed in 6 mL of 20 ppm aqueous solutions of M2+ (M = Pb, Hg, and Cd) for 72 h. The resulting samples were filtered and washed repeatedly with water and acetone to remove any unreacted metal solution and then dried under vacuum. The resulting samples were characterized by employing PXRD, FT-IR, and EDS analysis (Figures S9–S14).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of MOF-808-cys-M (M2+ = Pb2+, Hg2+, and Cd2+)

35 mg of MOF-808-cys was immersed in 6 mL of 20 ppm aqueous solutions of M2+ (M = Pb, Hg, and Cd) for 72 h. The resulting samples were filtered and washed repeatedly with water and acetone to remove any unreacted metal solution and then dried under vacuum. The resulting samples were characterized by employing PXRD, FT-IR, and EDS analysis (Figures S9-S14).

elements.content: 35 mg of MOF-808-cys was immersed in 6 mL of 5 ppm aqueous solutions of M2+ (M = Pb, Hg, and Cd) for 24 h. The resulting samples were then filtered and washed repeatedly with water and acetone to remove any unreacted metal solution. The metal-encapsulated solid samples obtained were then dried under vacuum, and ICP-OES analyses of the samples were carried out after decomposing them with nitric acid (trace metal grade). To realize the heavy metal removal efficiency, the initial and final concentration of the metal ions in the solution was determined by ICP-OES after 24 h. Pb2+, Hg2+, and Cd2+ showed 99.2, 99.6, and 99.2% removal efficiency, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Heavy-Metal Ion Capture Performance

35 mg of MOF-808-cys was immersed in 6 mL of 5 ppm aqueous solutions of M2+ (M = Pb, Hg, and Cd) for 24 h. The resulting samples were then filtered and washed repeatedly with water and acetone to remove any unreacted metal solution. The metal-encapsulated solid samples obtained were then dried under vacuum, and ICP-OES analyses of the samples were carried out after decomposing them with nitric acid (trace metal grade). To realize the heavy metal removal efficiency, the initial and final concentration of the metal ions in the solution was determined by ICP-OES after 24 h. Pb2+, Hg2+, and Cd2+ showed 99.2, 99.6, and 99.2% removal efficiency, respectively.

elements.content: 35 mg of MOF-808-cys was soaked in a 20 ppm aqueous solution of Cd2+ for 72 h to ensure maximum uptake. The metalated sample was named MOF-808-cys-Cd. MOF-808-cys-Cd was then filtered and soaked in a glass vial that contained 1.5 mL of deionized water and maintained at 60 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the sample was filtered, thoroughly washed with water, followed by acetone, and dried at room temperature. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.18 wt % for CdS1@MOF-808).
elements.clean_text:

35 mg of MOF-808-cys was soaked in a 20 ppm aqueous solution of Cd2+ for 72 h to ensure maximum uptake. The metalated sample was named MOF-808-cys-Cd. MOF-808-cys-Cd was then filtered and soaked in a glass vial that contained 1.5 mL of deionized water and maintained at 60 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the sample was filtered, thoroughly washed with water, followed by acetone, and dried at room temperature. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.18 wt % for CdS1@MOF-808).

elements.content: These samples were synthesized similarly as CdS1@MOF-808, except for the Cd2+ aqueous solution having a concentration of 50 ppm for CdS2@MOF-808 and 150 ppm for CdS4@MOF-808. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.84 wt % for CdS2@MOF-808 and 3.56 wt % for CdS4@MOF-808).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of CdS2@MOF-808 and CdS4@MOF-808

These samples were synthesized similarly as CdS1@MOF-808, except for the Cd2+ aqueous solution having a concentration of 50 ppm for CdS2@MOF-808 and 150 ppm for CdS4@MOF-808. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.84 wt % for CdS2@MOF-808 and 3.56 wt % for CdS4@MOF-808).

elements.content: CdS NPs were synthesized following a previously reported procedure. Cadmium nitrate [Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O] was dissolved in deionized H2O for the preparation of the Cd2+ stock solution (4 × 10–5 M, 100 mL), which was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (4 × 10–2 M, 100 mL) and stirred for 30 min. A solution of sodium sulfide (Na2S) in deionized H2O (3.75 × 10–5 M, 100 mL) was prepared and added dropwise to the Cd2+ stock solution, and the pH of the system was adjusted to 14. The as-synthesized CdS NPs were washed thrice with water to remove any unreacted substrates and collected by centrifugation. The as-synthesized CdS NPs were characterized by PXRD (Figure S7a) and had their diameters in the range of 1–3 nm, as validated from TEM (Figure S7b).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of CdS NPs

CdS NPs were synthesized following a previously reported procedure. Cadmium nitrate [Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O] was dissolved in deionized H2O for the preparation of the Cd2+ stock solution (4 × 10-5 M, 100 mL), which was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (4 × 10-2 M, 100 mL) and stirred for 30 min. A solution of sodium sulfide (Na2S) in deionized H2O (3.75 × 10-5 M, 100 mL) was prepared and added dropwise to the Cd2+ stock solution, and the pH of the system was adjusted to 14. The as-synthesized CdS NPs were washed thrice with water to remove any unreacted substrates and collected by centrifugation. Photocatalytic H2 evolution experiments were carried out in a 75 mL stoppered flask. 5 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 35 mL of H2O, and subsequently, 3 mL of TEA was added to the dispersion. The suspension was then ultrasonicated to make a homogeneous dispersion, which was then purged with Ar to remove all other dissolved gases. The reaction mixture was then irradiated using a 300 W xenon lamp (Newport) fitted with a visible band-pass filter (400–800 nm) to block the UV light. The evolved gas was analyzed by gas chromatography [Agilent 7890B gas chromatograph which uses a thermal conductivity detector referencing against a standard gas mixture (H2/N2) with a known concentration of H2]. We measured the intensity of the light source using a power meter (Newport-843-R). The measured intensity during the catalytic reaction (λ = 400–800) was 98.2 mW/cm2. All solid samples were activated at 120 °C under 1 × 10–1 Pa vacuum in a Quantachrome sample cell for 24 h prior to commencing photocatalytic reactions.

Preparation of the Working Electrode for Mott–Schottky and Impedance Measurements

2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and isopropyl alcohol (IPA) in a 1:1 ratio and 14 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was added to an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. Glassy carbon electrodes (4 mm diameter) were used as working electrodes. Before the experiments, the glassy carbon electrode was polished on a polishing cloth to obtain a mirror-like surface. 8 μL of the catalyst ink was drop-cast on the glassy electrode surface and left to dry for 6 h at room temperature. The Mott–Schottky experiments were performed by employing frequencies of 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz with a 10 mV amplitude with various applied potentials using a platinum wire counter electrode and a standard Ag/AgCl reference electrode. EIS measurements were carried out by applying an AC voltage of 10 mV with the frequency ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz in the three-electrode system.

Preparation of the Working Electrode for Transient Photocurrent Measurements

2.5 mg of the sample along with 1 mL of Milli-Q water and IPA in a 1:1 ratio and 15 μL of Nafion (5 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) was taken in an Eppendorf tube and sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous slurry. 500 μL of this slurry was coated on a 1 cm × 1 cm indium-doped tin oxide glass plate and dried at room temperature. The Ag/AgCl electrode was deployed as the reference electrode, and a platinum plate was used as the counter electrode. The transient photocurrent responses were studied under visible-light irradiation conditions (300 W xenon arc lamp).

SynthesisMicrocrystalline Powder Samples of MOF-808

Microcrystalline powder samples of MOF-808 were prepared following previously reported procedures. Benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) (0.21 g, 2 mmol) and ZrOCl2·8H2O salt (0.97 g, 6 mmol) were dissolved in DMF/formic acid (24.5 mL/24.5 mL) and placed in a screw-capped glass vial, which was then heated at 130 °C for 2 days. Subsequently, a white precipitate was collected by filtration and washed thrice with 25 mL of fresh DMF. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was then immersed in 5 mL of anhydrous DMF for 3 days, wherein DMF was replaced three times per day during this period. The DMF-exchanged compound was filtered and immersed in 15 mL of water, followed by anhydrous acetone, 3 days each. The solvents were replaced three times per day in a similar manner. The acetone-exchanged sample was then dried under vacuum for 24 h at room temperature followed by activation at 120 °C for 24 h to yield the desired compound (yield: 0.7 g, 79% based on Zr). 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.28 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:5.0. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C23H18O32 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2]: Zr, 40.42; C, 20.41; H, 1.34%. Found: Zr, 40.38; C, 20.10; H, 1.32%.

Synthesis of MOF-808-cys

Activated MOF-808 (0.100 g) was immersed in an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (0.1 M, 6 mL). The contents were kept in a screw-capped glass vial for 14 days. During this period, the l-cysteine solution was renewed every 4 days. The white precipitate was then filtered and washed with water several times to remove any trace of unreacted l-cysteine. Finally, the white solid powder obtained was dried under vacuum conditions to yield MOF-808-cys. 1H solution NMR spectra of the digested sample (400 MHz, D2O, ppm) δ: 8.20 (s, BTC), 8.26 (s, HCOOH), peak area ratio (BTC/HCOOH) = 6.0:0.86. Anal. Calcd. for Zr6C31H38O32N4 = [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)­(C3H7NO2S)­(H2O)2]: Zr, 35.57; C, 24.23; H, 2.47; N, 3.67%. Found: Zr, 34.23; C, 25.08; H, 2.68; N, 3.37%.

Heavy-Metal Ion Capture Performance

35 mg of MOF-808-cys was immersed in 6 mL of 5 ppm aqueous solutions of M2+ (M = Pb, Hg, and Cd) for 24 h. The resulting samples were then filtered and washed repeatedly with water and acetone to remove any unreacted metal solution. The metal-encapsulated solid samples obtained were then dried under vacuum, and ICP-OES analyses of the samples were carried out after decomposing them with nitric acid (trace metal grade). To realize the heavy metal removal efficiency, the initial and final concentration of the metal ions in the solution was determined by ICP-OES after 24 h. Pb2+, Hg2+, and Cd2+ showed 99.2, 99.6, and 99.2% removal efficiency, respectively.

Synthesis of CdS<sub>1</sub>@MOF-808

35 mg of MOF-808-cys was soaked in a 20 ppm aqueous solution of Cd2+ for 72 h to ensure maximum uptake. The metalated sample was named MOF-808-cys-Cd. MOF-808-cys-Cd was then filtered and soaked in a glass vial that contained 1.5 mL of deionized water and maintained at 60 °C for 48 h. Subsequently, the sample was filtered, thoroughly washed with water, followed by acetone, and dried at room temperature. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.18 wt % for CdS1@MOF-808).

Synthesis of CdS<sub>2</sub>@MOF-808 and CdS<sub>4</sub>@MOF-808

These samples were synthesized similarly as CdS1@MOF-808, except for the Cd2+ aqueous solution having a concentration of 50 ppm for CdS2@MOF-808 and 150 ppm for CdS4@MOF-808. The amount of metal sulfide formed was determined by ICP-OES analysis (1.84 wt % for CdS2@MOF-808 and 3.56 wt % for CdS4@MOF-808).

Synthesis of CdS NPs

CdS NPs were synthesized following a previously reported procedure. Cadmium nitrate [Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O] was dissolved in deionized H2O for the preparation of the Cd2+ stock solution (4 × 10–5 M, 100 mL), which was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of l-cysteine (4 × 10–2 M, 100 mL) and stirred for 30 min. A solution of sodium sulfide (Na2S) in deionized H2O (3.75 × 10–5 M, 100 mL) was prepared and added dropwise to the Cd2+ stock solution, and the pH of the system was adjusted to 14. The as-synthesized CdS NPs were washed thrice with water to remove any unreacted substrates and collected by centrifugation. The as-synthesized CdS NPs were characterized by PXRD (Figure S7a) and had their diameters in the range of 1–3 nm, as validated from TEM (Figure S7b).

Synthesis of CdS/MOF-808-cys

MOF-808-cys was immersed in a colloidal dispersion of the as-synthesized CdS NPs in DMF (5 mL, 2 mg/mL), and the resulting reaction mixture was stirred overnight at 60 °C. The solid sample was collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol thrice. Finally, the solid sample was dried under vacuum for 6 h. As per ICP-OES analysis, the amount of CdS present was determined to be 3.82 wt %.

cln_elements.content:
In this study, we demonstrate the functioning of a heavy-metal ion trap formed by grafting l-cysteine (l-cys) onto Zr4+-based MOF-808 [Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2] via postsynthetic ligand exchange (PSLE) to form MOF-808-cys. l-Cys is well-known as a source of S2– for the synthesis of a variety of metal-sulfide NPs, many of which are prominent photo- and electrocatalyst systems. The tolerance of MOFs linked by Zr4+-based clusters towards harsh chemical and mechanical conditions makes them ideal platforms for introducing functionalities employing PSLE, and MOF-808 is itself a robust system with a wide pore arrangement. The resulting functionalized MOF showed structural retention and affinity towards heavy-metal ions such as Cd2+ in aqueous media. In situ growth of CdS NPs inside the MOF pores was realized at elevated temperatures under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, it is well established that the Zr4+ cluster is capable of acting as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic water splitting or CO2 reduction. Therefore, the confinement of CdS NPs in the MOF nanopores in close proximity to the Zr4+ cluster not only opens up a facile and shorter electron transfer channel that suppresses electron–hole recombination but also stabilizes the catalytic system by preventing self-agglomeration and photobleaching (). The observed rate of H2 evolution from water for CdS4@MOF-808 (composite with 3.56 wt % of CdS) is 10.41 mmol h–1 g–1. The pore confinement effect of CdS was realized by comparing the catalytic activity with that of the CdS/MOF-808-cys (catalyst with similar CdS loading but on the exterior MOF surface) nanocomposite, which showed 60 times lesser activity with much slower and inefficient electron transfer kinetics compared to CdS4@MOF-808, as realized by the transient absorption (TA) measurements.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Structural Characterization

Zr4+-based MOF-808 formulated as Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(H2O)2 has a 6,3 connected 3D framework with spn topology and possesses two types of cages: tetrahedral and adamantane. The adamantane cage, having an internal pore diameter of 16.1 Å, is formed by the tetrahedral cages acting as the vertices. To balance the charge, the coordination of the SBU is completed with five exchangeable formate ligands that are well-directed toward the spacious adamantane cage. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the as-synthesized MOF-808 (a) exhibited two peaks at 8.6 and 9.9°, typical of MOF-808. Importantly, the observed pattern demonstrated unshifted peaks when compared with the simulated pattern obtained from its single-crystal structure analysis. The as-synthesized MOF-808 was also characterized employing FT-IR spectroscopy (Figure S1) and 1H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S2). The morphology of MOF-808 was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), wherein octahedral particles of size around 200–250 nm were observed (d). The lattice fringe spacing calculated was 1.64 nm, which is typical for MOF-808, and the result is consistent with the pore size obtained from the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) methods based on N2 adsorption data at 77 K (d inset). N2 adsorption study (at 77 K) was performed to validate the permanent porosity of MOF-808 (b). The BET surface area was 2418 m2 g–1, which is in good agreement with the previous reports of Zr4+-based MOF-808. The high internal surface area, large cavity size, excellent stability in aqueous solutions, and, most importantly, the presence of appropriately oriented and exchangeable formate ions on the Zr6 cluster makes Zr4+-based MOF-808 an ideal platform for postsynthetic modification with l-cys. The robustness of the structure of MOF-808 after functionalizing with l-cys was confirmed by PXRD studies (a), where similar peak positions were observed when compared with the pristine MOF-808. 1H NMR studies of alkaline digested MOF-808 exhibited two characteristic peaks at chemical shift values of 8.28 and 8.20 ppm corresponding to the protons of benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate (BTC) and formate ligands. The peak integration ratio of these two peaks confirmed the presence of six BTC and five formate units in the framework. However, for MOF-808-cys, this resulting ratio indicated the presence of six BTC units and one formate unit, thereby confirming the successful exchange of four formate ligands by l-cys (Figure S4). The FT-IR spectra for MOF-808-cys showed two new peaks at 2310 and 1190 cm–1 corresponding to the S–H and C–N symmetric stretching, respectively, further confirming the presence of the l-cys molecule in the MOF-808 framework (Figure S3). TEM images of MOF-808-cys (e,f) reveal an octahedral morphology, thereby confirming no significant change in morphology upon covalent grafting of l-cys. The presence of S and N in the elemental mapping of MOF-808-cys (g and S5) also illustrates the incorporation of l-cys into the framework.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements (Figure S6) demonstrated weight loss in two steps and a total of 40 and 56% weight loss up to 800 °C for MOF-808 and MOF-808-cys, respectively. It was also observed that MOF-808-cys could maintain good thermal stability up to 250 °C, which is in good consistency with that of pristine MOF-808. A significant decrease in the N2 uptake (b) and the corresponding BET surface area from 2418 to 562 m2 g–1 further validates the incorporation of l-cys in the framework. The pore size distribution (c) showed a reduction of pore size from 1.60 to 0.86 nm after postsynthetic modification with l-cys. However, the cavity size for MOF-808-cys is still spacious enough for efficient mass transfer to take place.

In Situ Growth of Metal Sulfide NPs

l-Cys is widely used as a precursor in the synthesis of metal sulfides accredited to the presence of the thiol group. Initially, the metal ions interact with l-cys to form precursor complexes, which undergo decomposition to produce metal sulfide composites as the reaction temperature increases. When soaked in a 20 ppm aqueous solution of Cd2+, MOF-808-cys showed removal of Cd2+ ions owing to the presence of free metal-binding sites. This observation was evident from inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurements. Similar observations were found for other heavy-metal ions such as Pb2+ and Hg2+, and the samples were named MOF-808-cys-M (M2+ = Cd2+, Pb2+, and Hg2+). In concentrations as low as 5 ppm, MOF-808-cys is capable of acting as a heavy-metal ion trap for removing Cd2+, Pb2+, and Hg2+ from their respective aqueous solutions with a removal efficiency >99% (Table S1). The resulting solution contained metal ion concentrations lower than the admissible limits in drinking water standards of the WHO. PXRD patterns of the metal captured samples (Figure S9) exhibited unaltered peak positions compared to the l-cys-functionalized MOF-808, suggesting that the MOF structure is retained after the capture of metal ions. The successful binding of the heavy metal ions was confirmed from FT-IR spectra (Figure S10) as the intensity of the S–H symmetric stretching peak at 2310 cm–1 for MOF-808-cys shows a significant decrease upon capturing the heavy-metal ions from the aqueous solution. A small shift to higher wavenumbers observed for the peak can be accredited to the rigidification of the S–H bond upon metal ion coordination. TEM images of the MOF-808-cys-M samples illustrated the intactness of the octahedral morphology (Figure S11). The capture of the metal ions was further validated from the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images and the corresponding elemental mappings (Figures S12–S14). For real-time analysis, MOF-808-cys was also tested against water samples from a nearby waterbody, and the corresponding elemental mapping (Figure S15) showed ample amounts of Pb2+ and Hg2+ uptake. The MOF-808-cys-Cd samples obtained from the 20 ppm Cd2+ solution were subjected to heating at 60 °C to unravel the decomposition of l-cys and consequential formation of cadmium sulfide composites. From ICP-OES analysis, the wt % of CdS formed within the MOF pores was calculated to be 1.18%. Correspondingly, the sample was named CdS1@MOF-808. The CdS1@MOF-808 sample showed peaks corresponding to the metal sulfide NPs in its PXRD pattern (Figure S16). The N2 uptake and the BET surface area (b) showed an increase for CdS1@MOF-808 as compared to those for both MOF-808-cys and MOF-808-cys-Cd, which was in good accordance with the breaking of the l-cys moiety to form metal sulfide NPs at elevated temperatures. We hypothesized that MOF-808-cys acts as a template for the in situ growth of metal sulfide NPs within its nanosized cavities. This proposed phenomenon was validated from the TEM images of the metal captured samples which clearly showed NPs having diameters in the range of 1–2 nm under high magnification (a–c). The lattice fringe spacings (b inset) of CdS1@MOF-808 were calculated to be 0.33 and 0.19 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (220) planes of the cubic CdS system, respectively, thereby confirming our conjecture of in situ growth of metal sulfide NPs. This was further clarified from the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (c), which confirmed the presence of the two aforementioned planes for the crystalline CdS NPs.
